page.title: 04LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: TYRINGHAM AND FILGRAVE WERE ORIGINALLY 2 SEPARATE PARISHES BUT FILGRAVE CHURCH (ST MARYS) THOUGH STILL IN USE IN 1585, WAS DEMOLISHED IN 1758.TYRINGHAM CHURCH HAS BEEN IN USE SINCE THE 12th.CENTURY BUT MUCH REBUILT c.1872.IN RECENT TIMES THE FIRST SCHOOL AT FILGRAVE HAS BEEN CLOSED (1984) AND THERE HAVE BEEN 3 SHOPS AT DIFFERENT TIMES, BUT ALL HAVE CLOSED.GAYHURST HAS A POPULATION OF ABOUT 100 AND IN THE LATE 1960's IT ALSO LOST ITS ONE VERY SMALL SHOP AND SUB-POST OFFICE.AS A RESULT THE MAIN POST BOX WAS IN THE EARLY 1980'S MOVED TO THE OTHER SIDE OF THE ROAD.BUS SERVICES HAVE ALSO DECLINED e.g.THOSE RUN BY UNITED COUNTIES HAVE BEEN SCRAPPED AS AN ECONOMY MEASURE.IN THE 1860's A RAILWAY FROM NEWPORT PAGNELL TO OLNEY WAS STARTED BUT NEVER COMPLETED BUT SOME EARTHWORKS SURVIVE. GAYHURST HOUSE(16th.C) NOW FLATS.
